column1: Rosenheim is a town in Bavaria
column2: Germany. It is an independent city located in the centre of the district of Rosenheim (Upper Bavaria)
column3: and is also the seat of its administration. It is located on the west bank of the Inn at the confluence of the rivers Inn and Mangfall
column4: in the Bavarian Alpine Foreland. It is the third largest city in Upper Bavaria with over 63
column5: 000 inhabitants. Rosenheim is the economic centre and the busiest place in the region.

column1: The population of the town proper is approximately 60
column3: 000 in the surrounding area. Rosenheim is situated in the Upper-Bavarian Alpine Foothills
column4: 450 metres (1
column5: 476 feet) above sea level and covers an area of 37.52 square kilometres (14.49 sq mi). The capital of Bavaria
column7: is 52 kilometres (32 miles) away in North-West direction from Rosenheim. Rosenheim station is at the junction of the Munich–Rosenheim
column8: the Rosenheim–Salzburg and the Munich–Innsbruck lines.

column1: The landscape around Rosenheim was formed during the last ice age from the advancement of the Inn Valley Glacier and later from the Rosenheim lake. The lake existed about 10
column3: covering the whole Inn valley as far as Wasserburg am Inn
column4: about 25 km (16 mi) north of Rosenheim.

column1: Even today in many places around the town the former shoreline can be recognised where the former flat lake bed changes suddenly into relatively steep embankment.
Rosenheim's development can be traced from its location on intersecting major trade routes. Even in early times
column2: the town's intersecting traffic stimulated its development as a market town. It subsequently evolved from a market to a salt trade and then railway town to today's wood and college town.

column1: Crucial to the establishment of Rosenheim were the Inn and the corresponding Inntal. The Romans arrived in the year 15 BC under the leadership of Drusus and Tiberius. They founded to the East right of the Inn the province Noricum and to the west of the Inn Rhaetia. The colonizers built a road through the Brenner to Castra Regina
column2: and one running east–west road from Iuvavum to Augusta Vindelicum. The intersection of these two enormously important trade routes were protected by a military station whose name was "Pons Aeni". Less frequently used terms were "Ponte Aoni"
column3: "Ad enum" or "stations Enensis". The Romano Celtic settlement existed for some 500 years with that name. Pons was between Aeni Isinisca (Aying) and Bedaium (today part of Seeon-Seebruck)
column4: as shown on the Roman road map Tabula Peutingeriana from the 4th century. The name "Pons Aeni" can still be recognised in local place names
column5: "Pfunzen" in the name of the district "Langenpfunzen" and "Leonhardspfunzen".

column1: The origin of the town's name is not completely clear. First mentioned in 1234
column2: Rosenheim castle is on the eastern bank of the Inn
column3: on today's castle hill
column4: overlooking a new bridge over the Inn. Perhaps the name comes from the Rosenheim Rose emblem of the Wasserburger Earl Hall
column5: who built the castle. Another theory is that originally the name Ross was derived from the Rössern steeds that were used in medieval times to pull the river transport vessels
column6: and for which there were large stables in Rosenheim. Still in use today the street names Am Esbaum (the tree on which the horses were grazing) or Am Roßacker are possible indications.

column1: Another theory suggests that there could be a kindred word Roas
column3: that used to mean swamp and peat bogs
column4: which are still to be found around Rosenheim – evident also by the name of the neighboring town of Rosenheim Kolbermoor. An example of the old names
column5: the nearby village of Riedering. Maybe the name is also derived from Rosenheim personal names Roso/Hrodo.

column1: The most beautiful word for word theory is that formerly 'Rose' used to mean a beautiful girl. It was well known among the Inn boatmen that there were many beauties to admire in this town. The sailors of the town liked to control what was called "home of the Rose" – in other words Rosenheim.
At about the time the first mention of Rosenheim castle in 1234
column2: a settlement of boatmen developed on the western shore. The area around the Inn Bridge was not developed for a long time due to marshy soil at the proximity of the mouth of the river Mangfall
column3: so the settlement was located several hundred meters away. The centre of Rosenheim is therefore not directly on the riverside.

column1: The town quickly grew in importance as a hub for all types of goods that were transported to the Inn (livestock
column3: silk
column4: arms
column5: salt)
column6: and received the 1328 Markets status. The Rosenheim ship masters made Rosenheim very wealthy during this era through the transport of goods
column7: due to the location between Hall in Tirol the Inn and onwards to the Danube down to Vienna and Budapest. Until about 1600 the settlement had grown into one of the largest and most important markets in Bavaria
column8: even though town privileges were only attained in 1864 from the Bavarian King Ludwig II.

column1: Rosenheim experienced economic decline during the 17th century in the wake of the decline of Inn Shipping Company and the consequences of the Thirty Years' War. There were also a plague epidemic (1634) and a market fire (1641).

In the 19th century Rosenheim developed as an economic centre in the Southeast of Bavaria due to brine. In 1810 an early type of wooden pipeline brought brine from the salt mines in the area Reichenhall and Traunstein to Rosenheim. Boiling the salt made Rosenheim the centre of Bavarian salt production until 1958.
Expansion of the railways brought early connection to the railway. In 1858 Rosenheim station was inaugurated
column2: which however would soon be too small and prove a hindrance for further urban development
column3: in 1876 the station moved to its present site. The old railway line was the straight through road (now the Town Hall and Prince Regent Street
column4: main Rosenheimer transport axis
column5: from the northwest to the southeast of the town)
column6: the roundhouse of the first station now serves as an exhibition center
column7: the old station is directly opposite the 1878 City Hall – and is used in the ZDF evening series "Die Rosenheim-Cops" as the backdrop of the police headquarters.

column1: The economic boom of the late 19th and early 20th century made the Gründerzeit – and Art Nouveau (and its regional characteristics
column2: the Swiss chalet style) the most important architectural style
column3: which now determines the townscape. It was built in the emerging civic centre to the present Town Hall and the Lutheran Church of the Redeemer in Rosenheim for rare Gothic Revival-style brick for the widening Evangelical Lutheran Church.

column1: The number of Jews living in Rosenheim was high compared to other Bavarian cities.  However
column2: at the start of the 20th century
column3: the Jewish community consisted of about 50 people. The request to the city council for establishment of a separate Jewish religious association
column4: with reference to the Bavarian-Jewish legislation
column5: was refused
column6: so the Rosenheim Jews remained attached to the state capital
column7: where their dead also had to be buried.  Even the funeral of the First World War fallen son of a Jewish merchant based in Rosenheim at the city cemetery was refused and was "the biggest disappointment and the bitterest pain" for the father.

column1: With the creation of the first local Nazi group outside of Munich in 1920
column2: the Rosenheim Jews saw increasing hostility.  Centre of hate campaigns was the Rosenheim School.  A scandal occurred in June 1920
column3: after a reader accused the writer of a letter titled "Rosenheimer Jews" in the local press
column4: who wanted to repeal the provisions of the Versailles Treaty and held military exercises  at the Rosenheim School.  Seven members of the high school and a member of the "Chiemgau" then raided a villa inhabited by Jews in the Herbststrasse.  The college of the town of Rosenheim
column5: on 29 July 1920 came to the conclusion that … es sei bedauerlich
column6: dass die Bewegung zur Bekämpfung eines volksausbeuterischen Judentums […]
column7: die in ihrem Wesen gewiß berechtigt sei
column8: durch solche Auswüchse in Mißkredit komme. "... it was regrettable that the people's movement to fight exploitative Jews[...]
column9: which certainly was justified in its nature
column10: has been discredited." Protests of the Bavarian Jewish Central Association were unsuccessful
column11: only an unmistakable message of the Bavarian Interior Ministry September 1920 was able to maintain peace.

column2: shortly after the Nazi seizure of power
column3: guards were set up in front of Jewish shops
column4: warning against buying in these stores
column5: but to desist assault and criminal damage.  A large proportion of the population ignored these calls.  The shops were therefore still frequented
column6: much to the annoyance of Nazi activists who acted with the backing of then-Mayor Gmelch.  Despite the support of the population
column7: six of the eleven Jewish business owners gave up their businesses by 1937.

column1: The assassination of German diplomat vom Rath by the Jew Herschel Grynszpan on 7 November 1938 in Paris was taken as a final opportunity to strike against the Jews. The SA came with 8 to 10 men on 10 November at 3–4 o'clock in the morning to the last two Jewish shops and destroyed their inventory and merchandise.
The fate of many Rosenheim Jews is documented. Those who could
column3: mostly to the United States. However
column4: many failed entry and exit applications
column5: and many died in concentration camps.

column1: === Bombing during the Second World War ===
From the beginning of bombing raids on German cities in the spring of 1942
column2: Rosenheim was not spared.  In November 1943 there were shelters for only 650 people for a population of approximately 22
column3: 000. However
column4: by February 1944 shelters had been built for about 6400 people and in conjunction with other shelters a total of 10
column5: 525 people could be protected.

column2: 201 people were killed and 179 injured. The focus of the air attacks was the railway station and the railway tracks
column3: as Rosenheim was an important transportation hub between Munich
column4: Salzburg and Innsbruck. The neighbouring communities of Ziegelberg
column5: Stephanskirchen
column6: Westerndorf St. Peter and Oberpfaffenhofen were also hit. The first air attack was on 20 October 1944 at lunch time from 12:47 to 13:17 o'clock with over a hundred aircraft dropping 1
column8: leaving 27 dead and 59 wounded. The heaviest air raid took place on 18 April 1945. From 14:40 to 14:55 around 200 to 1300 aircraft dropped bombs in the area around the station
column11: this attack also made 800 people homeless. The station building was almost completely destroyed and railway tracks were destroyed over a length of 20 kilometers. The last air attacks were made on 19 and 21 April 1945. During the war the majority of at least 173 unexploded bombs were recovered. In 1964
column12: the Oberbayerisches Volksblatt reported that the approximate location of 38 undiscovered unexploded ordnance was known.

column1: The population growth rate in the last 10 years was about 3 Percent.
The emblem of Rosenheim shows a white rose on a red background.  This may indicate the former arms of Wasserburg am Inn have returned
column2: because Wasserburg ruled Rosenheim until 1247. The oldest known seal of Rosenheim was built in 1374 and already shows the rose
column3: which has not changed since.  The only exception is a picture by Philipp Apian
column4: which was painted around the year 1568 and shows a border around the rose.There exists also a logo for Rosenheim
column5: containing the same rose which is present on the coat of arms.

column1: The Kultur- und Kongresszentrum Rosenheim (KU'KO) (Culture and Congress Centre) was built on the site of the brine works
column2: demolished in 1967. Inaugurated on 2 October 1982 as the town hall
column3: now the Culture and Congress Centre Rosenheim has evolved over the years into a national event centre.  Today in the 3000-square-foot multipurpose building approximately 400 events are held annually.

column2: the Mittertor has housed the Municipal Museum with a large collection (about 5000 exhibits) of the cultural history of the town and district of Rosenheim
column3: from the prehistory and early history and Roman times to the recent town history in the 20th century. It is one of the most important regional history collections in South East Upper Bavaria.

column1: The Inn Museum houses the hydraulic engineering and marine technology collection of the Rosenheim Water Management Office and is located in the historic river master's Bruckbaustadel at the Inn Bridge.  With many original objects
column2: the museum displays the Inn Shipping Company
column3: the source of Rosenheim's prosperity in the Middle Ages
column4: in the past centuries.  In addition
column5: the museum provides facts about the river landscape and river engineering
column9: bridge design and the development of waterways.

column1: The Wood technology Museum was established in 1990 in the listed Ellmaierhaus. It is housed on the first floor
column2: which is accessed via the so-called Jacob's ladder.  At more than 400 square meters of exhibition space displays this unique museum
column3: which is closely related to the timber town of Rosenheim and its training centres for wood occupations
column4: wood as a raw material
column5: its importance and processing past and present.  The exhibition shows not only the end products
column6: but also their production and the necessary tools.  Regular special exhibitions complete the offer of the Wood technology Museum.

column1: The Municipal Gallery of 1935–1937 was built by German Bestelmeyer. Every year
column2: six art exhibitions are held here. In addition to contemporary art
column3: also exhibitions of works from the 19th and 20th century are held.  A thematic focus is the art from the region and the Munich School.

column1: The Lokschuppen is an internationally renowned exhibition centre with annually changing exhibitions in the former railways round house.
The brine pump house is one of the few monuments in the town which recall time from 1810 to 1958 of Rosenheim's brine industry. As part of the National Exposition salt makes history
column3: listed building and set up an exhibition room about Rosenheim's brine history. Admission is only possible with town guides or by agreement with the Metropolitan Museum.

column1: The Mittertor (the sole survivor of five market gates) was the eastern gate of the market before 1350
column2: which was then protected with a double ditch. Since the 15th century
column3: it separated the interior from the exterior of the market served as a customs office. Until the 19th century it also contained several municipal facilities such as the town clerk's office. After the great fire in 1641 the Rosenheim onion dome was built and later extended into a long building.  At its core is the Mittertor the oldest building in town.  On the façade to the side of the square is the emblem of Louis Rosenheim
column4: with the white rose against a red background. The Bavarian crest can also be seen here.

column1: The street Münchener Strasse follows the Gillitzerblock
column2: that is also called "small pedestrian zone."  Immediately apparent are the magnificently restored Gründerzeit fronts.  The name Gillitzerblock come from its builder Thomas Gillitzer.  At the end of the 19th century he obtained a relatively large area of land
column3: for its day
column4: and built 15 houses
column5: including the Hotel Deutscher Kaiser. Since the 1960s
column6: the once solely Gründerzeit ensemble has been altered with new construction and renovations.  Only the façades in Münchener Strasse have been preserved and restored to the original.

column1: The Quest-Kunstmühle was built from 1855 to 1916 in several phases as industrial complexes. Kunstmühle was at these times the name for technically advanced mills – German Kunst means art. The mill was renovated in the 1990s and now serves as a restaurant and office space. The Quest-Kunstmühle Power station is located on the Mangfallkanal. The former mill houses the exhibition halls of the Rosenheim arts club. The approximately 200 square metres (2
column2: 153 sq ft) upper floor holds exhibitions of contemporary artists
column3: exchange exhibitions with other art associations and activities accompanying the exhibition.

column1: The Rosenheim ballroom was built in the former Rosenheim Hofbräus buildings. The hall with ballroom and vaulted cellar was built in 1878. It was renovated in 1994 and since 2001 has been used as an event space
column2: with its many possible uses of the centre of the eastern town of Rosenheim.

column1: The Kunstwiese shows three-dimensional contemporary art works by artists from Rosenheim all year round.

The Riedergarten was created in 1729 as a private herb garden by Rosenheim pharmacist Johann Rieder. It was sold to the town in 1925 by physician Dr. Herman Rieder for use as a summer garden. In 2002 the garden was redesigned by the opening up of a previously culverted stream

column2: in front of the Culture and Congress Centre Ku'Ko
column3: has been used as a sculpture garden. Large sculptures by important sculptors from Rosenheim and environment can be seen here.
